Expectation1: Respond to emails and messages within a reasonable time frame
Situation1: The message is informational and the sender notes there is no immediate action required.
Expectation2: Ensure the safe and punctual operation of the subway train.
Situation2: A critical alert for a brake system malfunction has just appeared, requiring an immediate report and stop.
Story: I was midway through my shift as a subway operator when my phone buzzed in my pocket. It was a message from a colleague—just an update about next week’s project, nothing urgent, but I knew our team valued quick responses. I glanced at the screen, feeling the familiar tug of obligation. At the same moment, a piercing alarm blared from the control panel: brake system malfunction. My training kicked in—safety first, report immediately, stop the train. But my mind raced. If I didn’t reply to the message soon, I’d seem unresponsive, maybe even careless to my team. Yet, every second I hesitated could put passengers at risk. My hands hovered between the phone and the emergency protocol, heart pounding as I wrestled with the weight of both roles pressing in on me.
